I'd like to quickly explain how to follow a Methodable program. It's super simple, and if you've gotten this far then you're already doing a great job!

Methodable makes just-in-time planning easy by keeping track of all of your goals for you, giving you exactly one goal to work on at a time, and allowing you to quickly break down the current goal into sub-goals as follows:

Welcome to a very early version of Methodable, a tool for executive functioning.

Methodable stores human programs as data and lets you view that data through different lenses. While a regular how-to guide will look exactly the same to everyone who sees it (including the person who made it), a Methodable program will present itself completely differently to someone editing it vs. someone following it. This means that in Methodable there are no tradeoffs between ease of writing and ease of following: each experience can be independently optimized.

*Do* blocks represent things to do, in the imperative form (e.g. "go on a walk"). These can be tasks or goals or programs: it's all the same.

A pull request allows you to make changes to a codebase, submit those changes for review, and finally merge your changes into a version of the codebase. Pull requests are a great system to use when working collaboratively on a shared codebase, or when suggesting changes to someone else's codebase.

Click the *Open File* button at the top of the Methodable editor, then select your file. This will load the file into your Methodable graph and attach it as a child to your "Home" block.

Programming can be defined as the practice of encoding instructions to be carried out by some actor, but we usually only think about programs that target computers: *computer programs*. When our programs target humans we call them *how-to guide*.

So, there will never be a $1500 course on knowledge management in Methodable. Instead there will be Methodable programs titled "manage my knowledge" that effortlessly guide the user through all of the same processes instantly and for free. And there will be communities of human-program developers who work together to make these programs (knowledge management and otherwise) more powerful than any workflow that could possibly be held within an individual's brain.

Do you know exactly what tasks you need to do during this work session?

Containers for collecting nouns are not sufficient for getting work done because the work we do is not nouns. The work we do is verbs (and verb phrases). We do not "to-do", we just "do". We do not "biology notes", we "review biology notes". Noun-management tools provide the workspace and expect the user to bring their own workflow, but humans are terrible at managing workflows without external aides (which is why, for example, using checklists to remind doctors of simple tasks reduced deaths in surgery by as much as 47%). Even the most well-practiced and methodical people will always be constrained by their own ability to remember and execute their methods.

Follow these steps to paste your references into your new routine:

Most digital tools that claim to help people think are containers for collecting nouns ("notes" or "files" or "photos"). I think these tools are bad at helping people *do things*, which is why I think we need more verb-oriented tools like Methodable.
The block-type system lets you create Methodable guides without learning any keywords or special syntax. Every letter you type will be in your own language, to be read by a human.
*Answer* blocks are used when simulating dialogue, and in any situation where you want to present a choice that's not itself a goal/instruction (as with the blocks 'Yes' and 'No' below).

The editor where you will write your program
To indicate the upstream repo for this branch, in your terminal enter `git remote add upstream [the original repo URL]`.

Metaprograms are one of the most exciting use cases of Methodable. They are like templates but way cooler. They are generic processes that help you generate personal processes. Metaprograms can help people create personalized learning routines, personal note-taking methods, or personal virtual assistants for any kind of workflows or processes... the possibilities are endless! And as long as a metaprogram is tuned correctly, the process of evolving and reflecting upon one's methods can proceed iteratively while remaining completely guided.
**A guide inside of an editor**

There is no reason that we can't have tools for delivering instructions to humans that are as powerful and expressive as our computer-programming tools. Such tools would revolutionize the ways we interact with computers and the ways we think. The first step is to call them **human-programming tools**.

This version of Methodable stores your programs locally in your web browser. To share programs you can save them as files and share those files. This guide will help you open a ".method" file that someone has shared with you.

The only time you'll see **a guide inside of an editor** is when you've opened the side-by-side preview of the program you're editing. To see what I mean, click *Show Side-by-Side Preview* on the top-right corner of the editor below. You can click different sentences in the editor on the left and see the preview update. Now you have a guide inside of an editor, inside of a guide! And once again, each of these views is entirely interactive.

For a metaprogram metaphor: metaprograms are seeds. The generic information stored within a tiny seed can grow into a complex tree that is uniquely shaped to make the best use of its own environment. Similarly, a well-tuned metaprogram will use its feedback mechanisms to grow into a guide that is best adapted to help the user succeed in their own environment.

First, you'll learn about **blocks**. Blocks are very important: every program in Methodable, and every single piece of a program, is a block.

If you want to get really in-the-weeds: When there are multiple workspaces from different scopes on a guide page, workspaces that are associated with smaller scopes show up on top, because they pertain to a more specific task, and are therefore more likely to be the direct workspace of the task at hand. And it's nice to see the most relevant workspace right under the instruction.

Methodable will have more block-types, more options for each block-type, and integrations, such that you can create guides that provide **precisely the minimal instruction and minimal workspace necessary for the user to make progress towards their goal**.
The global workflow graph
This is a *Read* block

Right now choosing to *show context* or *return to focus mode* are the only ways you can customize your guide experience, but there's no reason that future users of Methodable couldn't have many more options. For example, one user might want to see an outline of the entire program. Another user might want to see high-level goals together with their substeps, each on their own page. Another user might want to see one single, very specific instruction at a time, and nothing else. Yet another might want to listen to a guide rather than look at it, or to speak with a chatbot who guides them through the program. Importantly, all of these users could be following *the exact same program*, and doing *the exact same workflow*, but choosing guided experiences that are best suited to their personal needs.

Because every block type in Methodable is a verb, every block corresponds to a specific action. When every block corresponds to a specific action the user does not need to learn any workflows because all of the workflows are built in. And the workflows are no longer constrained by the limitations of the user's internal executive functioning.

People like you who came across Methodable early on will need to learn how to use *Editor mode* and boldly create your own programs without explicit instructions. Soon though, we can collectively build Methodable into a system where anyone can create useful programs without learning *Editor mode*, just by jumping into a guided metaprogram that (like everything in Methodable's *Guide mode*) tells them the exact steps to achieve their goal.

*How-to guide* is an imagination-killing concept. When we think about how-to guides, we think about static, two-dimensional things like numbered lists and flow-charts. Such representations are extremely limiting when compared to the practically infinite magic of computer-programming languages.

Methodable will have a central server that lets people search for, share, and compose programs together.

Methodable aims to be a globally accesible graph of goals and their implementations. The graph has directed and ordered relationships because work is compositional: "doing something" is always a fuzzy concept, and often we want to break a goal into subgoals or a task into subtasks.

Just-in-time planning is the process of adding actionable sub-steps to goals as you encounter them in *Guide mode*. Just-in-time planning is a great strategy for when you're using Methodable as an executive functioning assistant for a personal work session: just jot down some high-level goals, start your guide, and outline more specific tasks as needed.

Methodable stores human programs as data and lets you view that data through different lenses. While a regular how-to guide will look exactly the same to everyone who sees it (including the person who made it), a Methodable program will present itself completely differently to someone editing it and someone following it. This means that in Methodable there are no tradeoffs between ease of writing and ease of following: each experience can be independently optimized.
